metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (Cosmic-ray observation system of soil moisture of Sidaoqiao Superstation, 2021)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from a Cosmic-ray Soil Moisture Observing System of soil moisture of Sidaoqiao Superstation from January 1 to December 31, 2021. The site (101.1374° E, 42.0012° N) was located in the Ejina Banner in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The elevation is 873 m. The bottom of the probe was 0.5 m above the ground; the sampling interval was 1 hour.
The raw COSMOS data include the following: battery (Batt, V), temperature (T, C), relative humidity (RH, %), air pressure (P, hPa), fast neutron counts (N1C, counts per hour), thermal neutron counts (N2C, counts per hour), sample time of fast neutrons (N1ET, s), and sample time of thermal neutrons (N2ET, s). The distributed data include the following variables: Date, Time, P, N1C, N1C_cor (corrected fast neutron counts) and VWC (volume soil moisture, %), which were processed as follows:
1) Data were removed and replaced by -6999 when (a) the battery voltage was less than 11.8 V, (b) the relative humidity was greater than 80% inside the probe box, (c) the counting data were not of one-hour duration and (d) neutron count differed from the previous value by more than 20%; 2) An air pressure correction was applied to the quality-controlled raw data according to the equation contained in the equipment manual; 3) After the quality control and corrections were applied, soil moisture was calculated using the equation in Zreda et al. (2012), where N0 is the neutron counts above dry soil and the other variables are fitted constants that define the shape of the calibration function. Here, the parameter N0 was calibrated using the in situ observed soil moisture by SoilNET within the footprint; 4) Based on the calibrated N0 and corrected N1C, the hourly soil moisture was computed using the equation from the equipment manual. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Zhu et al. (2015) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

background: The acquisition of regional surface soil moisture has long been a research challenge. In recent years, the use of cosmic ray fast neutron methods to measure regional surface soil moisture has made significant progress. As a novel non-destructive measurement method for medium-scale soil moisture, the cosmic ray fast neutron method can obtain soil moisture within a source area of approximately 300 meters in radius. The larger measurement source area fills the gap between traditional point observations and remote sensing large-area observations. Traditional measurement methods include: gravimetric method (oven-drying method), neutron gauge method, capacitance method, tensiometer method, time-domain reflectometry (TDR), and frequency-domain reflectometry (FDR). These measurement methods are all destructive and point-based, with measurement scales mostly at small scales, poor spatial representativeness, and difficulty in obtaining information on the regional distribution of soil moisture. Feasibility studies on remote sensing monitoring of soil moisture began in the 1960s, with applied research starting in the mid-1970s. Remote sensing technology allows for rapid and large-area monitoring of soil moisture, but the soil moisture obtained through remote sensing is an average value at the pixel scale, with spatial resolutions generally ranging from tens of meters (aerial remote sensing) to tens of kilometers (satellite remote sensing), and it only provides instantaneous values at the time of aircraft or satellite overpass, making it impossible to obtain continuous data, which limits the application of large-scale remote sensing measurements in practical soil moisture monitoring. There is a gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale remote sensing monitoring, which is the inability to obtain regional soil moisture information at the scale of farmland or small watersheds. Similarly, in the process of validating remote sensing-derived soil moisture, it is not possible to obtain the required pixel-scale soil moisture data. In recent years, research on measuring surface soil moisture using cosmic ray fast neutrons has gradually attracted attention. The intensity of cosmic ray fast neutrons above the surface is inversely related to soil moisture content. By setting up neutron probes above the ground to measure the intensity of cosmic ray fast neutrons, surface soil moisture content can be inferred. The cosmic ray fast neutron method is a passive, non-invasive medium-scale soil moisture measurement method, with a measurement radius of about 300 meters and an effective measurement depth of 12 to 76 cm.
research objective: This article utilizes cosmic ray instruments to conduct long-term continuous monitoring of soil moisture in the Zhangye region of the middle Heihe River basin, and compares the results with data from Wireless Sensor Networks (WSN) to analyze the reliability of cosmic ray observations. The article analyzes the experimental results of regional soil moisture observations conducted in the Zhangye oasis farmland, indicating that the cosmic ray soil moisture observation system can effectively obtain regional soil moisture content. It not only accurately captures long-term time series soil moisture at the farmland scale but also provides meaningful surface validation data for remote sensing inversion of soil moisture.
challenges: There is a gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale monitoring through remote sensing, which makes it difficult to obtain regional soil moisture information at the scale of farmland or small watersheds. Similarly, in the process of validating soil moisture retrieved from remote sensing, it is challenging to acquire the required pixel-scale soil moisture data. Hydrogen atoms in the cosmic ray source region are not only present in soil moisture but also in lattice water, soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor. The presence of these hydrogen atom sources inevitably affects the propagation of fast neutrons. Zreda et al. pointed out that the presence of lattice water reduces the detection depth of cosmic rays; however, under the assumption that lattice water and soil organic matter remain constant, these effects can be eliminated through in-situ soil moisture calibration of the source region. In sparsely vegetated areas, the influence of vegetation can also be eliminated based on in-situ soil moisture calibration, but under rapidly growing vegetation, the moisture content of the vegetation has a certain impact on observations, and there is currently no comprehensive method to correct for this. The presence of water vapor affects the measurement source region of cosmic rays, and MCNPX simulations indicate that the detection radius under saturated water vapor is about 10% lower than that under dry air.
methods: The datasets used in this article are all derived from the 2012 "Heihe River Basin Eco-Hydrological Comprehensive Remote Sensing Observation Experiment," which mainly includes cosmic ray soil moisture datasets, wireless sensor network datasets (Soil-NET part), and rainfall datasets (Daman Station). During soil moisture observation, only a fast neutron probe needs to be installed; at the beginning of this experiment, only one fast neutron probe was installed for soil moisture observation. This article utilizes cosmic ray instruments to conduct long-term continuous monitoring of soil moisture in the farmland of the Zhangye area in the middle reaches of the Heihe River and compares it with soil moisture wireless sensor network data (Wireless Sensor Network, WSN) to study the reliability of the cosmic ray observation results.
dataset: The cosmic ray soil moisture dataset mainly includes raw fast neutron data, raw atmospheric pressure data, etc., with a sampling frequency of 1 hour. Fast neutron data can be used to infer soil moisture information in the study area. SoilNET mainly contains observation data from 50 SoilNET soil moisture/temperature nodes located within the MODIS pixel of the Daman Super Station. Each node can connect to 4 SISOMOP (Simple Soil Moisture Probe) soil moisture/temperature probes, which measure soil moisture and temperature at depths of 4, 10, 20, and 40 cm, with 19 of them distributed within the cosmic ray source area. The sampling frequency of SoilNET nodes is 10 minutes. This study primarily uses SoilNET node soil moisture data to validate cosmic ray observation results, requiring the aggregation of the original 10-minute data into 1-hour data for synchronization with cosmic ray data. The rainfall dataset (Daman Super Station) mainly includes raw rainfall data, with a sampling frequency of 10 minutes. During use, the original data needs to be aggregated into 1-hour data to analyze the relationship between cosmic ray soil moisture changes and rainfall.
findings: The cosmic ray soil moisture observation system can effectively obtain regional soil moisture content, not only accurately capturing long-term time series soil moisture at the farmland scale but also providing genuinely meaningful surface validation data for remote sensing inversion of soil moisture. Comparisons show that cosmic rays reflect a surface-level change in soil moisture, which can effectively indicate the trend of soil moisture changes beneath the farmland surface. After excluding irrigation period data, the correlation coefficient significantly increased to 0.86, and the RMSE decreased to 0.028 m³/m³.

Definition.Question: What is the role of cosmic ray neutron sensing in measuring regional soil moisture, and how does it compare to traditional methods?
Definition.Answer: Cosmic ray neutron sensing is a method for measuring regional soil moisture that captures data from a large area, approximately 300 meters in radius, offering a bridge between traditional point measurements and large-scale remote sensing. Unlike traditional methods such as gravimetric or capacitance techniques, which are invasive and limited to small scales, cosmic ray neutron sensing is passive and non-intrusive, providing a mid-scale measurement of soil moisture. This method is particularly useful in filling the gap between point measurements and satellite-based large-area observations.

Definition.Question: How do environmental factors such as vegetation and atmospheric conditions affect the accuracy of cosmic ray neutron sensing in soil moisture measurement?
Definition.Answer: Environmental factors like vegetation and atmospheric conditions can significantly influence the accuracy of cosmic ray neutron sensing for soil moisture measurement. Hydrogen atoms present in vegetation, water vapor, and soil organic matter can impact the propagation of fast neutrons, thus affecting the measurements. While some of these influences can be mitigated through in-situ calibration, challenges remain in accurately accounting for the effects of rapidly changing vegetation and saturated water vapor levels on the sensing radius and depth.

Definition.Question: What are the main data quality control steps necessary when preparing cosmic ray neutron data for soil moisture analysis?
Definition.Answer: The main data quality control steps in preparing cosmic ray neutron data for soil moisture analysis include: removing data with low battery voltage, filtering out observations with high relative humidity, ensuring the sampling time is consistent, and excluding data with significant fluctuations in neutron counts. After these steps, pressure correction is applied to adjust the neutron counts, followed by calibration to establish the baseline neutron count (N0) under dry soil conditions. This involves comparing neutron data against actual soil moisture measurements obtained from soil samples or dense sensor networks.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of cosmic-ray neutron probes for soil moisture measurement compare to traditional methods like TDR or FDR in terms of scale and spatial representation?
Comparison.Answer: Cosmic-ray neutron probes provide a mid-scale, non-invasive method for soil moisture measurement with a measurement radius of approximately 300 m, bridging the gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale remote sensing. Traditional methods like TDR or FDR are invasive and offer small-scale, point measurements with limited spatial representation.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of measuring soil moisture using cosmic-ray neutron methods differ from those encountered in wireless sensor network deployments?
Comparison.Answer: Cosmic-ray neutron methods face challenges from hydrogen presence in non-soil components like vegetation and atmospheric moisture, affecting neutron propagation. Wireless sensor networks, however, are influenced by discrete sampling points and sensor calibration, focusing on local soil moisture variability rather than broader spatial coverage.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be inferred about regional soil moisture distribution by comparing data from cosmic-ray neutron sensors to wireless sensor networks?
Interpretation.Answer: The comparison of cosmic-ray neutron sensor data with wireless sensor network data can reveal the reliability of cosmic-ray observations in capturing regional soil moisture. It shows that cosmic-ray neutron sensors effectively provide long-term, continuous monitoring of soil moisture at a regional scale, which can serve as an accurate ground validation for remote sensing-derived soil moisture data.

Interpretation.Question: How do cosmic-ray neutron observations address the limitations of traditional point measurement and remote sensing techniques in soil moisture monitoring?
Interpretation.Answer: Cosmic-ray neutron observations fill the gap between traditional point measurement, which lacks spatial representation, and remote sensing, which provides instantaneous values at pixel scale but lacks continuous data. These observations offer a non-invasive method to measure soil moisture over a medium scale with a radius of approximately 300 meters, providing valuable data for regional soil moisture distribution.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise from the presence of hydrogen atoms in non-soil moisture sources when using cosmic-ray neutron detection for soil moisture measurement, and how can these challenges be mitigated?
Interpretation.Answer: The presence of hydrogen atoms in sources like lattice water, soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor can affect the propagation of fast neutrons, potentially influencing soil moisture measurements. These challenges can be mitigated by conducting in-situ soil moisture calibration within the measurement area to account for constant sources like lattice water and soil organic matter, and by adjusting for vegetation effects in sparsely vegetated areas. However, rapidly changing vegetation and water vapor remain complex to correct accurately.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to the necessity of using cosmic ray neutron sensing as opposed to traditional soil moisture measurement techniques in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Cosmic ray neutron sensing is used in arid regions due to its capability to cover a larger measurement area with a radius of about 300 meters, bridging the gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale remote sensing. Traditional methods such as gravimetric methods, neutron probes, and time-domain reflectometry are point-based and invasive, while cosmic ray neutron sensing is non-invasive and offers a broader spatial coverage, providing more representative soil moisture data for regional distribution analysis.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is data screening important in the process of analyzing cosmic ray neutron data for soil moisture measurement?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Data screening is crucial for ensuring the reliability and accuracy of cosmic ray neutron data. It involves removing data points that fall below specific voltage thresholds, exceed relative humidity limits, or deviate from the standard sampling interval, as well as eliminating outliers with large fluctuations in neutron counts. This process helps in maintaining the integrity of the dataset by reducing noise and correcting for environmental factors such as pressure variations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What challenges necessitate the calibration of cosmic ray neutron data to accurately calculate soil moisture content?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Calibration of cosmic ray neutron data is necessary due to the influence of hydrogen atoms from sources other than soil moisture, such as lattice water, organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor. These sources can affect neutron propagation, and calibration involves soil moisture correction to account for these influences. The calibration process is also essential to determine the dry soil neutron count (N0), critical for accurate soil moisture calculations.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using a cosmic-ray neutron method for soil moisture measurement compared to traditional methods like gravimetric or remote sensing techniques?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a cosmic-ray neutron method for soil moisture measurement allows for non-invasive, mid-scale measurements with a radius of about 300 meters, bridging the gap between point observations and large-scale remote sensing. This method provides more representative data for regional soil moisture distribution and offers continuous data over time, which traditional methods may not offer due to their point-based nature or lack of temporal continuity.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects of integrating wireless sensor network data with cosmic-ray neutron data on understanding soil moisture variability?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating wireless sensor network data with cosmic-ray neutron data can enhance understanding of soil moisture variability by providing high-resolution, point-based measurements that complement the broader coverage of cosmic-ray data. This integration allows for cross-validation and comprehensive analysis, enabling more accurate depiction of soil moisture dynamics across different scales and improving the overall quality of soil moisture datasets.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use cosmic-ray neutron sensing for long-term monitoring of soil moisture in arid and semi-arid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Cosmic-ray neutron sensing is crucial for long-term monitoring of soil moisture in arid and semi-arid regions because it provides a non-invasive, medium-scale method to obtain soil moisture data over a large area, bridging the gap between traditional point measurements and remote sensing. This approach allows for accurate assessment of soil moisture dynamics in these regions, which is vital for understanding the interactions within oasis–desert ecosystems and supporting sustainable development.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives are pursued by integrating data from cosmic-ray neutron sensors and wireless sensor networks in soil moisture studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The integration of data from cosmic-ray neutron sensors and wireless sensor networks aims to validate the reliability of cosmic-ray observations by comparing them with high-resolution soil moisture data from wireless sensors. This approach helps to ensure accuracy and provides a comprehensive view of soil moisture conditions, which is essential for improving remote sensing inversion validation and understanding soil moisture distribution at the field or watershed scale.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in calibrating cosmic ray neutron data to accurately measure soil moisture in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The calibration process involves determining N0, which is the fast neutron count under dry soil conditions. This is achieved by measuring soil samples within the measurement area to obtain actual soil moisture content and comparing it with the corrected fast neutron data. This allows for recalculating N0 to align the observed data with actual conditions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is data quality ensured during the collection of cosmic ray neutron measurements for soil moisture estimation?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data quality is ensured through a multi-step screening process: eliminating data with voltage less than or equal to 11.8 volts, relative humidity greater than or equal to 80%, sampling time intervals not within 60±1 minutes, and fast neutron counts with hourly fluctuations greater than 200. Missing or excluded data are filled with a placeholder value of -6999.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approaches are used to address the challenges of hydrogen atom interference in cosmic ray neutron measurements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To address hydrogen atom interference from sources like lattice water, soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor, site-specific soil moisture calibration is conducted. While lattice water and stable soil organic matter effects can be negated through calibration, vegetation effects pose challenges in rapidly growing vegetation areas, and water vapor presence alters the detection radius by about 10%, as shown by MCNPX simulations.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the collection of soil moisture data using cosmic-ray neutron sensing in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of cosmic-ray neutron sensing technology allows for the non-invasive measurement of soil moisture over a large area, filling the gap between traditional point measurements and remote sensing. This method can effectively gather soil moisture data within a radius of approximately 300 meters and at a depth of 12 to 76 cm, providing a comprehensive view of soil moisture distribution in the region.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of wireless sensor networks enhance the reliability of soil moisture data collection in agricultural settings?
Enablement.Answer: Wireless sensor networks (WSN) offer a means to compare and validate cosmic-ray neutron sensing data by providing detailed soil moisture and temperature data at multiple depths from numerous observation points. By integrating WSN data, researchers can ensure the reliability and accuracy of the cosmic-ray neutron sensing results, offering ground-truth verification and enabling comprehensive monitoring over time.

Enablement.Question: What challenges do high humidity levels pose in the collection of cosmic-ray neutron data, and what methods are used to address these issues?
Enablement.Answer: High humidity levels can affect the accuracy of cosmic-ray neutron data by influencing the propagation of neutrons. To address this challenge, data collection involves screening out observations with relative humidity above 80%, and pressure corrections are applied to the neutron data to account for atmospheric conditions. This ensures that the resulting data is more accurate and reliable for interpreting soil moisture.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in obtaining continuous soil moisture data at a regional scale using traditional methods?
Expectation.Answer: Traditional soil moisture measurement methods like weighing, neutron probe, capacitance, tensiometer, and time-domain reflectometry are often point-based, invasive, and limited to small-scale measurements, making it difficult to capture regional scale soil moisture distribution.

Expectation.Question: Why is there a need for developing new methodologies to bridge the gap between point measurements and large-scale remote sensing in soil moisture monitoring?
Expectation.Answer: There is a gap between point measurements and remote sensing in terms of spatial resolution and temporal continuity. While remote sensing provides large-scale data, it lacks continuous temporal coverage and detailed spatial information at the farm or small watershed scale, which is critical for accurate soil moisture monitoring.

Expectation.Question: Why might cosmic-ray neutron sensing be considered a promising approach for regional soil moisture measurement compared to other existing technologies?
Expectation.Answer: Cosmic-ray neutron sensing offers a passive, non-invasive method with a measurement radius of approximately 300 m and an effective depth of 12 to 76 cm, providing a middle ground between point measurements and large-scale remote sensing, and effectively capturing area-wide soil moisture data.

Judgmental.Question: How might the integration of cosmic-ray neutron sensing improve the accuracy and representativeness of soil moisture measurements compared to traditional methods?
Judgmental.Answer: Cosmic-ray neutron sensing offers a non-invasive, large-area measurement capability with a radius of approximately 300 meters, bridging the gap between point-scale traditional methods and large-scale remote sensing. This method captures soil moisture changes over a wider area, providing more comprehensive data that can better represent regional soil moisture variability.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in using cosmic-ray neutron sensing for soil moisture measurement in regions with sparse vegetation or rapidly changing plant growth conditions?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges arise from the presence of hydrogen atoms in sources other than soil moisture, such as vegetation, lattice water, and soil organic matter, which can affect neutron readings. While corrections are possible, rapidly changing vegetation poses difficulties, as current methods may not fully account for the variability in plant water content, influencing the accuracy of soil moisture measurements.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways can long-term observational datasets from oasis–desert ecosystems contribute to understanding the interactions between energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Long-term datasets provide valuable insights into the dynamics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, critical for assessing the balance and stability of oasis–desert ecosystems. These datasets help in understanding the ecological and socioeconomic impacts of these interactions, supporting strategies for sustainable development and carbon neutrality goals in arid and semi-arid regions.

However, challenges include interference from hydrogen atoms in lattice water, soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor, which can affect the neutron count and require specific corrections or calibrations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection techniques used for monitoring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection techniques for these ecosystems involve long-term observations using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for flux data, as well as automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data. These stations gather data on radiation, soil heat flux, air temperature, humidity, wind speed, soil moisture, and groundwater tables. The dataset encompasses energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, which are essential for understanding oasis-desert interactions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential methods for improving the accuracy of soil moisture measurements using cosmic-ray neutron sensing in the presence of varying vegetation cover.
Request/Directive.Answer: To improve accuracy, it is crucial to calibrate the cosmic-ray neutron sensing method by accounting for the hydrogen sources in vegetation, which can impact neutron propagation. While in sparse vegetation areas, field soil moisture calibration can mitigate these effects, rapidly growing vegetation presents challenges that lack comprehensive correction methods. Further research is needed to develop reliable correction techniques for dynamic vegetation conditions.
